--- title: "Day 35" title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: images/lake.jpg data-background-size: contain data-background-opacity: "0.5" subtitle: "Math 216: Statistical Thinking" author: "Bastola" format: revealjs: html-math-method: mathjax mathjax-url: "https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/mathjax/3.2.2/MathJax.js" theme: [default, scss/main.scss] slide-number: true preview-links: auto history: true chalkboard: src: drawings.json transition: slide background-transition: fade touch: false controls: true --- ## Describing associations between two quantitative variables {.font80} ::: bqt Data: each case $i$ has two measurements - $x_i$ is explanatory variable - $y_i$ is response variable ::: ::: out-t ::: font80 A scatterplot is the plot of $(x_i, y_i)$ - form? linear or non-linear - direction? positive, negative, no association - strength? amount of variation in $y$ around a "trend" ::: ::: ## Example: Associations in Car dataset {.font80}

Various Associations of quantitative variables in Cars data
## Direction of relationship {.font80}
::: bq ::: font80 [positive association:]{.bold-text} as $x$ increases, $y$ increases - age of the husband and age of the wife - height and diameter of a tree [negative association:]{.bold-text} as $x$ increases, $y$ decreases - number of cigarettes smoked per day and lung capacity - depth of tire tread and number of miles driven on the tires ::: ::: ## Understanding Correlation Coefficients $r$ and $\rho$ {.font60} ::: {.cle9} - Correlation coefficients, denoted $r$ (sample) or $\rho$ (population), measure the linear relationship between two variables. - Strength varies as $r \approx \pm 1$ (strong), $r \approx 0$ (weak). - **Direction**: - Positive ($r > 0$) or negative ($r < 0$) linear association. - **Calculation and Interpretation**: - $$ r = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n \left(\frac{x_i - \bar{x}}{s_x}\right) \left(\frac{y_i - \bar{y}}{s_y}\right)}{n-1} $$ - Considers deviations from the mean, normalized by standard deviations. - Interpretation: $r = 1$ (perfect positive), $r = -1$ (perfect negative), $r = 0$ (no relationship). - **Visualization & Outliers**: - Scatterplots reveal the clustering around the regression line; outliers can heavily influence $r$. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Example R code to calculate correlation cor(data$x, data$y) # Note: Order of x and y doesn't affect the outcome. ``` ::: ::: ## Car Correlations {.font80}

Correlations of various variables in Cars data
## Deterministic vs. Probabilistic Models {.font80} ## Deterministic vs. Probabilistic Models {.font80} ::: {.cle7} - **Deterministic Model**: Assumes a perfect, predictable relationship without error, e.g., $y = 1.5x$. - **Probabilistic Model**: Incorporates randomness, modeling $y$ as: $$ y = 1.5x + \text{random error} $$ - **General Form**: $$ y = \text{Deterministic component} + \text{Random error} $$ - Assumes mean of random error is 0, aligning $E(y)$ with the deterministic component. ::: ## Linear Regression Model {.font60} ::: {.cle6} - **Goal**: To find a straight line that best fits the data in a scatterplot. - **Regression Equation**: $$ \hat{y} = b_0 + b_1x $$ - $x$: explanatory variable - $\hat{y}$: predicted response variable - **Parameters**: - **Slope** ($b_1$): Increase in predicted $y$ for every unit increase in $x$. $$ b_1 = \frac{\text{change }\hat{y}}{\text{change } x} $$ - **Intercept** ($b_0$): Predicted $y$ value when $x = 0$. $$ \hat{y} = b_0 + b_1(0) = b_0 $$ ::: ## ## Simple Linear Regression: Fitting and Evaluation {.font80} ::: {.cle12} - **Steps**: 1. Hypothesize the deterministic component (e.g., $E(y) = \beta_0 + \beta_1x$). 2. Estimate model parameters using least squares. 3. Assess the fit and use the model for prediction. - **Residuals**: - Geometrically, a residual is the vertical distance from each point to the regression line, helping measure model fit. ::: ## Residuals

## Implementing Regression Analysis {.font80} ::: {.cle6} - **Example**: Understanding the relationship between temperature and cricket chirp rate. - Model cricket chirp rate as a function of temperature. - **Methodology**: - Utilize observed data to fit a linear model that predicts cricket chirp rate based on temperature. - Calculate deviations to assess model fit and refine parameters as needed. ::: ## Data Overview {.font50} | Observation | Temperature (Â°F) | Chirp Rate (chirps/15 sec) | |-------------|------------------|---------------------------| | 1 | 89 | 20 | | 2 | 72 | 16 | | 3 | 93 | 20 | | 4 | 84 | 18 | | 5 | 81 | 17 | | 6 | 75 | 16 | | 7 | 70 | 15 | | 8 | 82 | 17 | | 9 | 69 | 15 | | 10 | 83 | 16 | | 11 | 80 | 15 | | 12 | 83 | 17 | | 13 | 81 | 16 | | 14 | 84 | 17 | | 15 | 76 | 14 | ## ```{=html} ```

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
